argumentText:
The assumption that $|f_n(x)| \le M_n$ for every $x$ guarantees that
each numerical series $\sum_n f_n(x)$ converges absolutely. We call the
limit $f(x)$.

To see that the convergence is uniform: let $\epsilon>0$. Then there
exists $K$ such that $n>K$ implies $\sum_{n>K} M_n < \epsilon$. Now, if
$k>K$,

$$|f(x)-\sum_{n=1}^k f_n(x)| = |\sum_{n>k} f_n(x) | \le
\sum_{n>k} |f_n(x)| \le \sum_{n>k} M_n < \epsilon$$

The $\epsilon$ does not depend on $x$, so the convergence is uniform.
names: proof of Weierstrass' criterion of uniform convergence
